title: Ecological Urban Design: Connecticut Coastal Planning and Engineered Landscapes
xlist:
Same As: ARCH 4226, section 01
Same As: F&ES 888, section 01
description:
This course lays the groundwork for an interdisciplinary group of students including the School of Architecture, the School of Forestry and Environmental Studies and the School of Engineering and Applied Sciences undergraduate engineering students to collaboratively explore climate adaptation and define ecologically driven urban engineering and design approaches for Connecticut’s coastal floodplains. Student teams co-investigate and co-design real world strategies for projects along Connecticut’s coast that incorporate engineering principles alongside landscape architecture, urban ecology, ecological restoration, and urban design. Students focus on understanding multiple actors from state agencies, to regional planners, to municipal managers, and homeowners. There is additional focus on municipal to site scale interventions and opportunities to incorporate sensors and designed ecological experiments as components of floodplain adaptation. 

The course will enroll 8 Forestry students, 8 Architecture students and 8 junior or senior ENAS students working in teams.
